title: Fighting cancer with funny moustaches: "We were not the norm. Cancer is very serious and we were not serious"
text:
‚ÄúWE SIT IN the privileged position that we came up with a brilliant idea ‚Äì and everyone got on it‚Ä¶ and then we harnessed it to help change the world.‚Äù

As statements go, it‚Äôs a big one ‚Äì but the man talking about changing the world is Justin Coghlan (known as JC), one of the co-founders of the Movember Foundation charity.

If you see men sporting strange and wonderful moustaches in November, then you can blame Movember. (And if you can‚Äôt grow a moustache, there are other ways to be a Mo Bro or Mo Sista.) But what it has also been doing is raising hundreds of thousands of dollars for cancer charities across the world, including Ireland.

What started off as a once-off idea to celebrate a friend‚Äôs birthday in Australia has gone on to become a global movement.

On average globally, men die six years before women, while men suffer from illnesses and diseases that are often preventable through minor lifestyle changes. What Movember does is try to shine a light on ways to get men to the doctor early, and get them thinking about health as a priority.

Where it all began

JC

In 2003, friends Travis Garone and Luke Slattery held the first Movember in honour of Garone‚Äôs birthday in Melbourne. In 2004, they registered it as an official charity, raising over ‚Ç¨30,000 for the Prostate Cancer Foundation of Australia. By 2006 it had received Australian charity status.

It soon gathered more participating countries, and Movember Ireland was official launched in 2008.

Neil Rooney, Movember director in Ireland, explained the impact of Movember fundraising here:

From money raised by Irish Mo Bros and Sistas, we now provide two full time nurses dedicated to helping men deal with the physical and mental side effects of prostate cancer who are based in Dublin and Galway.

In 2004, JC came on board to work with all things Movember in Queensland. When TheJournal.ie meets him 12 years later in Dublin, the charity has gone on to totally surpass his initial expectations.

Movember has raised over ‚Ç¨516 million, and funded over 1200 projects focusing on prostate cancer, testicular cancer, poor mental health and physical inactivity. The Irish arm of Movember has linked up with groups like the Irish Cancer Society and there is already a rake of events planned for November this year.

‚ÄúIt was the perfect storm at the time,‚Äù says JC of Movember‚Äôs foundation. ‚ÄúIt was like the Beatles ‚Äì it was four very different people coming together and creating magic in men‚Äôs health.‚Äù

When they first started, the guys knew that Movember was something very new on the charity scene. ‚ÄúWe were not the norm, charity is very conservative and cancer is very serious and we were not serious,‚Äù points out JC.

‚ÄúWe were doing a fun thing at that time which was just moustaches, for a serious cause.‚Äù That led them to coin the phrase ‚Äúhaving fun doing good‚Äù.

The impact of Movember isn‚Äôt lost on the four Movember founders. ‚ÄúWe are sitting here today humbled and privileged to be the world‚Äôs largest men‚Äôs health organisation,‚Äù says JC now.

But he says that what has kept him awake at night was that they didn‚Äôt waste the opportunity ‚Äì or money. Instead, they‚Äôve turned the charity into a massive, worldwide foundation that involves a dash of marketing, and perhaps even a spark of hipsterism too.

Changing lives

Movember‚Äôs aim, says JC, is to encourage men to get checked out so that prostate cancer can be detected early. If it‚Äôs caught early, you‚Äôve got a 96% survival rate for five years and above, says JC.

‚ÄúIf you get detected after and you present late, it‚Äôs called metastasising ‚Äì your survival rate for five years plus is 29%.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you get checked early it‚Äôs a game-changer,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs why we kind of took it on.‚Äù He says the charity has advanced prostate cancer by 50 years.

He doesn‚Äôt use the phrase ‚Äúcure cancer‚Äù, because ‚Äúno one‚Äôs ever gonna cure cancer ‚Äì you will manage cancer, you will live with and beyond cancer‚Äù.

Did getting involved in Movember change how he took care of his health? ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt find it difficult to talk about [beforehand], but it changed me. Because the more I got involved, and the more we did and more we expanded ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt wake up in a day now and I don‚Äôt have a conversation about suicide prevention.‚Äù

This is another element of the Movember work ‚Äì trying to get guys to talk in an effort to prevent suicide rates from climbing. (The latest figures show that young men are at the greatest risk of suicide in Ireland.)

JC points out that as men get older ‚Äúthe big stuff‚Äù ‚Äì illness, family changes, work changes ‚Äì can happen. ‚Äú[And] they‚Äôve got no one to turn to.

So what we want men to do is check in with your mates before you check out. So it‚Äôs that one conversation. And women have this amazing‚Ä¶ they can talk face to face [and] never lose their network, guys have this shoulder to shoulder, so you‚Äôll be watching a sport event, you‚Äôll be doing something or tinkering with something ‚Äì that‚Äôs when guys are going to open up. They‚Äôre not even going to look at each other, they‚Äôre going to talk, ‚Äòoh how‚Äôs that going‚Äô.

JC, also aims to get men to move 30 minutes a day ‚Äì and understand their historical data. ‚ÄúIf prostate cancer is in your family you are 2.5 times more likely to get it,‚Äù he points out.

‚ÄúWalk for 30 minutes a day, understand what‚Äôs going to kill you, and you know it‚Äôs that old adage diet and exercise ‚Äì you don‚Äôt have to be a triathlete, you just have to understand everyone is built differently.‚Äù

The changing face of charity

Source: Sasko Lazarov/Photocall Ireland

Movember was created around the same time as Facebook, and the latter has helped the spread of fundraising phenomena like the ice bucket challenge. Has this threatened Movember‚Äôs long-running work? Not in JC‚Äôs eyes.

‚ÄúI applaud it,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúPeople copy us all the time ‚Äì not the ice bucket challenge but people copy us all the time and people go to me ‚Äòoh they are ripping off Movember‚Äô. They are doing good, so let them do it, right? It doesn‚Äôt have to be about that.‚Äù

The biggest concern I personally have about the ice bucket challenge is they made so much money so fast and it had this rolling effect. I think it negatively impacted people giving, and not for us, and then it kind of exposed ‚Äòoh that person got way too much money‚Äô‚Ä¶ everyone started to question themselves in giving and that I think affected the whole industry and it changed perceptions on giving which is a good and a bad thing.

It‚Äôs not a bad thing for Movember, says JC, ‚Äúcos we‚Äôre accountable for every dollar we spend‚Äù.

Despite the emergence of social-media based fundraising events, Movember has steadily been able to keep up ‚Äì and grow ‚Äì its work.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just so privileged, we get to wake up every day ‚Äì we change the world, right,‚Äù enthuses JC.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a pretty powerful thing and if we can just save one man every day and do that for us we‚Äôre just kicking away at a journey.

‚ÄúI know that sounds corny and cheesy but we want to change the world, that‚Äôs what we want to do and we think we‚Äôre doing a pretty good job of it with men‚Äôs health and we‚Äôll continue to do that.‚Äù

Movember in Ireland

Source: Declan Branagan

This year, Movember is hitting the road in Ireland to gather men‚Äôs health stories across the country.

Movember is capturing a national snapshot of men and women who have personal stories to share on men‚Äôs health, and will use these stories and images as part of their awareness and education campaign this year.

Declan Branagan, a survivor who is one of the participants from Dublin said:

Two years ago I was diagnosed with prostate cancer. As the founder and CEO of my company eXpd8, it was hard to switch off from work and focus on myself. However, my diagnosis was also a real eye-opener. Every face tells a story. My story is one of many, and if it encourages other guys to go and get checked, even better‚Ä¶ Three seconds saved my life. It‚Äôs so important to be able to speak openly about it, and discuss it.

To find out how you can do your bit to get involved in the 2016 campaign, head to ie.movember.com.

title: How Pat Shortt made a comedy about emigration and 1916
text:
YOU KNOW WHO Pat Shortt is.

He‚Äôs Tom from Father Ted, one half of D‚ÄôUnbelievables and the star of Killinaskully.

He‚Äôs also a film actor, comedian and chart-topping singer.

But what he represents is a quintessentially Irish brand of humour and satire. He is the Irishman‚Äôs Irishman.

Shortt‚Äôs new film The Flag, which was released in cinemas on Friday, tells a very Irish story which weaves emigration, Irish identity and 1916 together in a caper comedy.

Shortt plays Harry Hambridge, a man from a small town now living in London. After coming home for his finds out that not only did his grandfather raise the Irish flag above the GPO, but the British are keeping it in an army barracks.

With a fill of porter, Harry decides he‚Äôs getting it back and a heist plan is put in place.

While the film takes plenty of shots at the British establishment, it is essentially an examination of Irishness, something Shortt has also been seen doing on the small screen in TV3‚Ä≤s excellent Small Town.

Sitting in a Dublin hotel, Shortt says that the comedy can easily be used to pose questions.

‚ÄúWhen you play Irish characters, even from a comic point of view, you have to analyse them and think about them and the impact different things have had.

‚Äú(You have to think about) how they react to it, whether it‚Äôs religion, religion, whatever or in the case of The Flag that pride in being Irish.‚Äù

The Flag‚Äôs closing scenes see Harry at this year‚Äôs 1916 commemorations asking about Ireland as a nation ‚Äì where we are and whether we actually honour the ideals of the 1916 dead.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a great part of the movie.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs a great thing in a comedy ‚Äì that you can be serious about ourselves and look at ourselves.‚Äù

Our world

Looking at Irish people is something Shortt has plenty of experience with.

But he says that the Irishness of his output is rooted in an affection for Irish life ‚Äì and the confidence we have in ourselves.

#Open journalism No news is bad news Support The Journal Your contributions will help us continue to deliver the stories that are important to you Support us now

‚ÄúFor a very small nation of people, our large world is the little world around us.

‚ÄúSo the guy who‚Äôs living in a rural village in Ireland ‚Äì his world is as important as London or New York. And I think that‚Äôs a great confidence thing.

‚ÄúThat innocent kind of look at the world.‚Äù

He says his own character in the film ‚Äì complete with Italia 90 jersey and Irish vinyl ‚Äì ‚Äúis in London, but may as well be in Ireland‚Äù.

And what‚Äôs next for him?

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to do anything only keep working,‚Äù he laughs.

‚ÄúI have a new live show that I‚Äôm looking forward to touring around the country with and taking to America and Australia.‚Äù

Indeed, Shortt‚Äôs popularity abroad shows that Irishness doesn‚Äôt end at the borders.

The Flag is in cinemas now.

title: This Irish doll-maker has signed a book deal with famed children's publisher Penguin
text:
IRISH DOLL-MAKER Arklu has signed a publishing deal with children‚Äôs books giant Penguin, which has worked with authors such as famed novelist Roald Dahl.

The Donegal-based firm created Lottie in 2012, a doll that was intended to look and take part in activities like a real child.

Since its launch, the doll has grown in popularity, selling more than half a million figurines and accessories, and is now set to be the subject of several Penguin books.

The two companies have agreed a three-year publishing contract. The first books to be released under the partnership are due to launch in May 2017.

The company said that the books will be an extension of the ‚ÄòLottie, Finn and friends collection‚Äô, and will follow the adventures of three nine-year old friends as they navigate family, friendship and childhood.

Launch

Two books will be published, one a fiction title for young readers, and one a sticker dressing-up book, which will be focused on stargazing and space.

A further two titles, one fiction and one activity book, will then follow in September 2017.

A 'robot girl' Lottie doll Source: Youtube

The books will be part of Penguin‚Äôs Puffin collection for children. Penguin has worked with several of the best-known children‚Äôs authors including Roald Dahl, whose books include The BFG and Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, and Jeff Kinney, who wrote Diary of a Wimpy Kid.

A spokeswoman for Arklu said that final details of the launch, such as how many shops the books will be available in, are still under discussion.

However, she added: ‚ÄúIt is an international contract. The dolls are sold in 30 countries and we would hope that the books will follow suit.‚Äù

Arklu managing director Ian Harkin said that following the deal the firm will be ‚Äúintroducing almost 20 new products in 2017 including playsets, storage units, playmats and buildings for the first time‚Äù.

‚ÄúBeing based on a child is what makes Lottie and Finn unique, taking kids on adventures as opposed to performing adult activities or careers. The books complement this ‚Äì like Lottie they will be real characters just like the kids themselves.‚Äù

Arklu managing director Ian Harkin Source: Arklu

Startup winner

Leanne Gill, the publisher of licensed properties at Penguin Random House Children‚Äôs, said that the company is ‚Äúdelighted to be the publishing partner for Lottie Dolls‚Äù.

Arklu was also recently selected by Google as the winner of its latest Adopt a Startup programme for Ireland - a prize which includes thousands of euro in free credit for the tech giant‚Äôs services.

Speaking at the time, Harkin told Fora the company also has plans to unveil an app, which was part of work it did with Google.

Written by Paul O‚ÄôDonoghue and posted on Fora.ie

title: Irish women are being given the chance to star in a movie with Mel Gibson
text:
MEL GIBSON IS on the hunt for Irish women to star in his new film.

The Braveheart actor is in Ireland as he prepares to shoot his new movie The Professor and the Madman.

And now he needs women with a very specific look to join the cast which will include Sean Penn and Natalie Dormer.

According to the casting call, suitable candidates must have ‚Äúno fake tan or nails. Hair must be natural colour- no dyed hair.

‚ÄúHair must medium or long in length ‚Äìno shaved heads or undercuts. ‚ÄúNo plucked/shaved eyebrows or obvious tattoos and body decorations.

They must also have a waist size of 26-28 and a bust of 34-36.

You can check out the full specifications here.

Gibson has been spotted in a number of Dublin bars and restaurants over the past month including Mulligan‚Äôs of Stoneybatter and FX Buckley‚Äôs in the capital.

title: Anne Doyle made her triumphant return to reading news on the Ray D'Arcy Show
text:
Weekly Podcast

The Explainer

The Explainer is a weekly podcast from TheJournal.ie that takes a deeper look at one big news story you need to know about. Listen now wherever you get your podcasts

title: New Yorkers are leaving each other loving post-it notes to support each other after the election
text:
NEW YORKERS STRUGGLING with post-election stress have found an outlet for the blues, by pouring their political souls onto sticky notes that fill walls of a Manhattan subway station.

In the days after Republican Donald Trump won the White House, Democrat Hillary Clinton‚Äôs loss brought many of her New York supporters to tears ‚Äî even in public.

Enter 28-year-old Brooklyn artist Matthew Chavez, known as Levee. He set up a table in a long tunnel of the Union Square station where he hands out the blank pastel notes on which straphangers scribble.

He calls this ‚ÄúSubway Therapy.‚Äù It‚Äôs free.

The notes are being left on the underground passageway that connects the 1 train to the L train on 14th St. Source: Mary Altaffer/PA

More than 1,500 people have shared their grief and anxiety since Wednesday, posting thoughts on the white subway tiles.

The uplifting art installation counterbalances what Clinton supporters say is Trump‚Äôs racism, bigotry and ignorance.

One note reads, ‚ÄúYou will not divide us. Love is everything.‚Äù Another says,

It doesn‚Äôt end today.

One says: ‚ÄúIf they go low, we go high,‚Äù echoing first lady Michelle Obama.

Another sticky note offers soothing words, saying, ‚ÄúEverything will be alright.‚Äù But a few feet over, another person wasn‚Äôt so sure: ‚ÄúWhat do we do now?‚Äù

There was an answer amid the sea of impromptu messages.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been through worse (meaning 9/11) and the city will unite,‚Äù the light pink sticky note said.

title: New cocktail of drugs could significantly improve outcomes for cancer patients
text:
A NEW COMBINATION of two drugs could extend the lives of thousands of people with kidney cancer.

Scientists say 40% of kidney cancer patients using the combined drugs saw their tumours significantly reduce in size, while 10% were left with ‚Äúno detectable sign of cancer‚Äù at all.

The two drugs, ipilimumab and nivolumab, work by stimulating the body‚Äôs own immune system to fight the cancer.

The study evaluated the drugs, at different doses, in previously-treated and treatment-na√Øve patients with metastatic renal cell carcinoma.

Renal cell carcinoma is the most common type of kidney cancer, accounting for approximately nine out of ten cases.

The overall response rate, the number of patients who saw a complete or partial reduction in their tumours, was 40%.

One in 10 patients treated with nivolumab 3 mg/kg + ipilimumab 1 mg/kg every three weeks for four cycles, followed by nivolumab 3mg/kg every two weeks, achieved a complete response, where no detectable sign of cancer remained.

These investigational data were presented during the 2016 European Society for Medical Oncology (ESMO).

Dr Conleth Murphy, Consultant Medical Oncologist, Bon Secours Hospital, Cork said, ‚ÄúIt is very promising to see these early results as they demonstrate that using two immunotherapy agents in combination has the potential to significantly improve outcomes for patients with advanced kidney cancer.

The degree of tumour shrinkage seen with combined therapy is particularly encouraging.

‚ÄúThe experience we have had with nivolumab in Irish patients with kidney cancer has been very impressive so I am hopeful that today‚Äôs data regarding the nivolumab + ipilimumab combination may further improve outcomes in the coming years.‚Äù

Each year, roughly 570 people are diagnosed with kidney cancer in Ireland and in the last 40 years the number of cases has doubled in men, and risen by 130% in women.

Approximately 254 people die from kidney cancer every year in Ireland. In cases of late-stage kidney cancer, it is estimated that only one in 10 patients will survive for five years or more in Ireland.

title: Here are some handy iPhone and Android gestures you might not know about
text:
AT THIS POINT, all of us know the basic swipe and tap gestures needed to use and navigate our smartphones.

But beyond that, there are a whole host of other gestures and ideas that you might not be familiar with. Some are specific to apps themselves while others can be used across the board.

Here are a few to get you started.

All (iOS and Android)

- Both iOS and Android have a zoom-in option available to users. Going into Settings (> General) > Accessibility > Zoom/Magnification Gestures to activate it. Depending on which one you use, it‚Äôs activated by tapping the screen three times with one finger, or double-tap with three fingers.

- On Google Maps, if you double-tap on the screen, you zoom in. However, what you might not know is if you continue holding down after the second tap, you can continue zooming in and out by swiping your finger up and down.

- When you‚Äôre typing, holding down on a specific key will bring up alternative characters (For example, holding down ‚Äòi‚Äô will bring up extra characters like ‚Äò√≠‚Äô).

- On Snapchat, if you‚Äôre recording a video, you can zoom in and out by swiping up and down.

- On Apple and Google Photos, you can select multiple photos by pressing select/holding down on one photo and dragging your finger over them. Handy if you need to bulk-delete photos.

iOS

- If you own an iPhone 6s or 7, force pressing the spacebar when typing lets you move it around. Easier than trying to tap or drag the pointer around.

- When you‚Äôre in an app, you can go back one screen by swiping right.

- You can have text read out to you anytime if you set it up. Go into Settings > General > Accessibility > Speech and activate Speak Screen. Now if you swipe down with two features, a floating control panel will appear where you can play/pause or adjust the reading speed.

- While not strictly a gesture (but handy to know), triple-clicking the home screen will bring up a list of accessibility shortcuts.

- In Photos, when you‚Äôre viewing a photo, you can just swipe down to minimise it instead of pressing the back button.

- If you‚Äôve scrolled too far down a screen, tapping the top of the screen ‚Äì where the time is ‚Äì will bring you back to the top.

- If you‚Äôre using the calculator, swiping will act as a backspace option.

- One that has been around for a while, shaking your phone when you‚Äôre typing will let you undo your last action.

#Open journalism No news is bad news Support The Journal Your contributions will help us continue to deliver the stories that are important to you Support us now

Android

- You know how swiping down from the top brings up notifications and another swipe down shows you quick settings? Well, you can access quick settings immediately by swiping down with two fingers.

- On notifications, long-pressing a notification will bring up extra options. For example, long-pressing a Gmail notification will let you change notification preferences.

- On Google Keyboard, holding down on the return button (the green button on the bottom right-hand corner) will give you the option to go into one-handed mode.

- If you‚Äôre having problems with your phone because of an app you installed, you can reboot to safe mode. Hold down the power button but instead of tapping Power Off, hold down until a safe mode option appears.

- On some versions of Android, holding down on the home button will bring up Now on Tap, which scans the screen and brings up search results based on it.

- If you‚Äôre using Chrome, swiping down from the address bar will bring up all the tabs you have opened. Alternatively, swiping left or right on the address bar will let you navigate between tabs.

title: Dublin before the internet: weight gain pills, big hair and swimming pools in nightclubs
text:
A NEW EXHIBITION in Dublin aims to bring visitors back to Ireland pre-internet, where women avoided being called skinny and Terry Wogan was a voice on pirate radio.

Brian ‚ÄòDoug‚Äô McMahon‚Äôs site Brand New Retro, has scanned and digitised images from Irish magazines that have never been put on the internet before.

After online success and a book, McMahon has moved on to a museum exhibition which opened in the Little Museum of Dublin this week.

Speaking to TheJournal.ie he says he is ‚Äúdelighted‚Äù with the end result, which brings together his love of retro pop with a snapshot of what Ireland was like in the 60s and 70s.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm delighted with it. It feels like it came together at the last minute, but It is exactly what I wanted as a medium for showing the collection.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs different, it‚Äôs an explosion of colour and information.‚Äù

Source: Brand New Retro

Be it a retro jukebox playing McMahon‚Äôs own 45s, early magazine interviews with Anne Doyle or information on Ireland‚Äôs first gay nightclub, the exhibition gives either a nostalgic blast from the past or an insight into an Ireland many of us haven‚Äôt seen.

And it is all sourced from McMahon‚Äôs own collection.

I grew up loving pop and when punk came around, me and my brother started a fanzine, which gave me an appreciation of what went into making magazines, so I rarely threw them away. So a built up a collection from there.

‚ÄúWhen I started the blog, it was to put up stuff I had done or was interested in that wasn‚Äôt on the internet.

‚ÄúAnd I found there was a load of Irish stuff that wasn‚Äôt on the internet.‚Äù

Source: Brand New Retro

McMahon‚Äôs collection now includes thousands of magazines from the 60s, 70s and 80s, but he still has a soft spot for certain things.

‚ÄúI like something that has a geographical reference and is of its time.‚Äù

He points to the exhibition‚Äôs main image, of Miss Ireland 1965 Gladys Waller sitting on a Morris Minor on the bridge to Bull Island in 1966 wearing clothes from Brown Thomas .

‚ÄúI get a great satisfaction out of the rejuvenation of things like that.

I love that people will see things for the first time. There‚Äôs something for everyone. I like that it‚Äôs interactive as well, that‚Äôs the experience.‚Äù

The exhibit runs in the Little Museum of Dublin until January.

title: Meet the man who's helping Irish children embrace their artistic sides
text:
PJ Lynch with costume designer Joan Bergin (left) Source: Sasko Lazarov/Photocall Ireland

WHEN YOU‚ÄôRE A child, reading and drawing can fit so easily into your creative world ‚Äì if you‚Äôre lucky enough to be introduced to them.

As Laureate na N√≥g, the children‚Äôs laureate, artist PJ Lynch could be just the man to introduce a whole new generation to the joy of art and reading.

One of the country‚Äôs most impressive and lauded illustrators, he has been awarded the Christopher Medal three times and been given the Kate Greenaway Medal on two occasions for his work on children‚Äôs books.

The Belfast native has been drawing from a young age, and managed to make illustration a career as well as a personal passion. It took him 30 years, but he‚Äôs even written his own book, The Boy Who Fell Off the Mayflower.

He‚Äôs has also collaborated with Ryan Tubridy on a forthcoming book called Patrick and the President which Tubridy has written and Lynch has illustrated.

‚ÄúIt was an honour‚Äù

For Lynch, taking on the role of laureate means spreading the word about art and literature to young people around Ireland. It‚Äôs not a role he takes lightly.

‚ÄúIt was a huge honour,‚Äù he says of the laureateship (the role was created in 2010). ‚ÄúIt was mind blowing ‚Äì the biggest honour of my career.‚Äù

He was particularly chuffed to be following in the footsteps of the previous laureates, Eoin Colfer, Siobh√°n Parkinson and Niamh Sharkey.

‚ÄúEoin was a storyteller and his laureateship was very much to do with stories ‚Äì I love stories but I‚Äôm artists and for me it‚Äôs got to be about making pictures,‚Äù he says of his intentions with the two-year role.

Lynch is almost evangelical about how children can benefit from reading. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really important, because I think whenever children read books it‚Äôs a way for them to slip into someone else‚Äôs situation, it‚Äôs a way for them to understand other people‚Äôs problems.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt helps people empathise,‚Äùhe says. ‚ÄúReading is absolutely vital for our development as human beings. It‚Äôs important.‚Äù

It‚Äôs interesting, then, that he admits that as a small child: ‚ÄúI did love reading but I didn‚Äôt read enough.‚Äù It wasn‚Äôt until he hit college that he got the reading bug.

With Oliver and Sam after their brilliant presentation on A Child of Books at the fabulous CBI conference. pic.twitter.com/TNO8q5oVtM ‚Äî PJ Lynch (@PJLynchArt) September 19, 2016 Source: PJ Lynch /Twitter

Lynch knows the importance of being inspired by other people. ‚ÄùI remember back when I was little when I used to watch artists drawing, I was so fascinated to see people drawing,‚Äù he recalls, calling the process ‚Äúreally magical‚Äù.

‚ÄúI want to share that process,‚Äù he explains. Part of that involves creating a video podcast series called The Big Picture, where he meets with artists and illustrators and gets them to talk about their work ‚Äì people like Oliver Jeffers and Chris Judge.

So I want to cover the whole range of drawing and I want to show how people draw and I want kids to get in and say ‚Äòwow, I love that drawing and I want to give it a go‚Äô.

‚ÄúArt was my thing‚Äù

Lynch, who has illustrated over 20 books, was the kid in the class who was always scribbling and sketching. ‚ÄúI think it was the thing I was best at in school, it was the thing I absolutely loved.

‚ÄúYou know you get a kid in the class who is the artist or the musician ‚Äì I was the artist and it was my thing, but I was always going to do something arty. In my family or my school I don‚Äôt think anyone had gone to art college. I was breaking new ground.‚Äù

But he got ‚Äúhuge support‚Äù from his parents ‚Äì ‚Äúat a time when other people might have said ‚Äògo out and get a proper job‚Äô‚Äù.

Lynch went to college in Brighton, where one of his tutors was the man behind The Snowman, Raymond Briggs.

‚ÄúHe was getting really successful ‚Äì he inspired a lot of us,‚Äù Lynch recalls. ‚ÄúLiving in England made it easy to get to London and make contacts with publishers. These days I think you can live anywhere and I think you can communicate through the internet.‚Äù

It‚Äôs a far cry from when he used to fax in illustration ideas to people.

What‚Äôs a typical day for Lynch? When we speak, he‚Äôs preparing to give a talk to some school children in Cork and do some drawing with them, as part of his laureateship.

‚ÄúTypically I get to do a bit of work in the studio,‚Äù he adds, though he loves the new opportunities the laureateship offers.

I do try to work 9 ‚Äì 5 and if I have a tight deadline I can really push the work out. Usually I get a year for a book. At the start I spend a lot of time reading and researching, probably dawdling. And towards the end I really work hard and fast. It depends on where I am in the project.

Since he has become more established, he‚Äôs also gotten to take part in large projects like a huge mosaic he worked on in Knock. It‚Äôs the height of a five-storey building.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping I will get the chance to do a big picture [like that] in Ireland [as part of the laureateship],‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI really want that image to be a testament to the whole idea of the imagination and children‚Äôs literature. I have a few sites in mind.‚Äù

Want a career in art?

If you are a young person who‚Äôs thinking of a career as an illustrator, Lynch has advice for you.

‚ÄúI would say it‚Äôs one of those jobs that you can do an awful lot by yourself at home, but I don‚Äôt want to just encourage people to do that. If you are a certain age you can go to art college and find a certain college that specialises in illustration. Some of the colleges here are pretty good on illustration as well. It‚Äôs one of those jobs that you don‚Äôt have to get the qualification before you get a go at it.‚Äù

He advises to keep practicing and studying ‚Äì and even try and make your own dummy illustrated book that you can send off to publishers, and make sure you get feedback on your work.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôve got an idea there‚Äôs nothing stopping you,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt is a brilliant job for anyone who‚Äôs interested in art.‚Äù

PJ Lynch will officially open the 20th Babor√≥ International Arts Festival for Children which runs in Galway from October 17 ‚Äì 23. On Monday 17 October, Lynch will take part in a panel discussion with fellow artists Tarsila Kr√ºse and Shona Shirley Macdonald, chaired by Alan Clarke, about their careers as illustrators. For more details, visit the festival website.

title: Stolen dog reunited with owner after being found on sale at a fair
text:
Joey the cavachon dog is reunited with his brother and owner Source: ISPCA

THIS IS THE emotional reunion of Joey the dog with his owner and brother Toby.

Joey, who is a Cavachon breed, went missing near his home on 3 October and, by Saturday, he was being offered for sale at the Ballinasloe Fair.

Suspicions were raised by members of the public and an ISPCA inspector scanned the dog.

Joey was microchipped so the ISPCA was able to track down the owner and reunite them.

Joey and Toby are now back together. Source: ISPCA

Investigation

The dog was taken into the care of the ISPCA and garda√≠ are now investigating the matter.

ISPCA chief inspector Conor Dowling said: ‚ÄúThis is further evidence, if it was needed, of the value of microchipping.

Without Joey‚Äôs microchip, we could not have established that he was missing and the ISPCA and garda√≠ would not have had grounds to intervene.

The ISPCA had four inspectors present on the three busiest days of this year‚Äôs Ballinasloe Fair.

In addition to Joey, inspectors seized a further 27 dogs and three horses.

#Open journalism No news is bad news Support The Journal Your contributions will help us continue to deliver the stories that are important to you Support us now

For ISPCA inspectors to seize animals, they must have grounds to believe that offences under the Animal Health and Welfare Act have been committed.

Demand

ISPCA CEO Dr Andrew Kelly highlighted the fact that the sale of dogs and other small animals at fairs is driven by demand and that, if people did not buy these animals, then they wouldn‚Äôt be offered for sale.

He said: ‚ÄúThis year in Ballinasloe we were made aware of a number of rescue organisations that were buying animals in order to ‚Äòrescue‚Äô them instead of raising their concerns with the ISPCA or An Garda S√≠och√°na.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhilst buying animals may be very tempting, it is the opinion of the ISPCA that it simply perpetuates the problem and the sellers will be back in future years with more animals to sell.‚Äù

title: Michelin star-winning Dublin restaurant booked out until next Autumn
text:
A DUBLIN RESTAURANT which scooped a Michelin star is booked out until August 2017 after a massive surge in demand.

Heron and Grey, which is located in Blackrock, south Dublin, has no tables left until next year since news of its win last week.

The team will start taking new bookings in the spring.

Damien Grey, one half of the team who set up the eatery, revealed the news this morning.

Whoops! We couldn't find this Tweet

We interviewed Rebecca Burr, editor of the Michelin Guide and she told TheJournal.ie that its work is not cut and dried.

We tend to hear that restaurants have phones ringing off the hook, but many already had very busy restaurants before that. Heron and Grey for example, is already very successful, we just came along and added what we thought.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no such thing as a typical Michelin-starred restaurant. I think that‚Äôs what makes the stars interesting.‚Äù

The addition of Heron & Grey to the guide last week increases to 10 the overall number of Michelin star restaurants in the Republic of Ireland.

#Open journalism No news is bad news Support The Journal Your contributions will help us continue to deliver the stories that are important to you Support us now

Others that held their awards from previous years are:

Restaurant Patrick Guilbaud, Chapter One, L‚ÄôEcrivain and The Greenhouse in the capital

Aniar and Loam restaurants, based in Galway city

Campagne and Lady Helen at Mount Juliet Hotel in Kilkenny

House Restaurant at Cliff House Hotel, Ardmore in Waterford.

With reporting by Paul Hosford

title: Celine Dion sends best wishes as Pat Kenny picks up IFTA Lifetime Achievement gong
text:
PAT KENNY PICKED up a Lifetime Achievement award and TV3‚Ä≤s Red Rock was among the big winners as the IFTA TV awards took place last night at the DoubleTree Hotel on Dublin‚Äôs Upper Leeson Street.

In what was perhaps an unexpected move, the video package played in advance of Kenny‚Äôs acceptance speech included a greeting from singer Celine Dion.

The Canadian star‚Äôs inclusion makes a little more sense if you take into account that Dion won the Eurovision back in 1988 (for Switzerland), when Kenny co-presented the contest from the RDS.

Pat Kenny and C√©line, back in '88 Source: RT√â

Enda Kenny (no relation, we assume) and his former RT√â colleagues Ryan Tubridy and Dave Fanning also sent tributes to the broadcaster, who now helms a weekday show on Newstalk, and began a new weekly current affairs programme on TV3 this week.

Last evening‚Äôs ceremony will be shown on TV3 tomorrow night.

Who else won?

Other big winners on the night were Brendan O‚ÄôCarroll, for his role in Mrs Brown‚Äôs Boys; Sharon Horgan, who picked up two awards including a Best Writer nod for Channel 4‚Ä≤s Catastrophe and comedian Al Porter, who was named as the ‚ÄòRising Star‚Äô.

The Liam Neeson-narrated 1916: The Irish Rebellion was the big winner in the documentary category.

Here is a list of the winners:

CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE‚ÄôS My Life Champion of the World ‚Äì Tyrone Productions

ANIMATION The Day Henry Met ‚Äì Wiggleywoo

COMEDY Bridget & Eamon

IRISH LANGUAGE An Klondike ‚Äì Ab√∫ Media

WRITER ‚Äì SOAP AND COMEDY Sharon Horgan ‚Äì Catastrophe

EDITING ‚Äì TELEVISION √öna N√≠ Dhonghaile ‚Äì An Innocent Man

SOUND ‚Äì TELEVISION Deoch an Dorais ‚Äì Dean Jones, Colm O‚ÄôRourke and John Brennan

CAMERA ‚Äì TELEVISION Michael O‚ÄôDonovan ‚Äì These Walls Can Talk

DIRECTOR ‚Äì SOAP AND COMEDY Jason Butler ‚Äì Bridget & Eamon

title: Mattress Mick's guide to life: "Believe in yourself
text:
THE CHARACTER OF Mattress Mick is big, brash and bold ‚Äì a bit quirky, a bit odd, and always guaranteed to put a smile on your face.

But behind the character are two men: the real Mick, Michael Flynn:

Michael Flynn Source: YouTube

And Paul Kelly, the guy who has helped create Mattress Mick and turn him into an online phenomenon.

Paul Kelly Source: YouTube

The relationship between the two men and their journey to nationwide fame is explored in a new documentary, Mattress Men, which doesn‚Äôt shy away from showing viewers the tough times the pair have had.

When TheJournal.ie goes to catch up with Flynn and Kelly in Mattress Mick‚Äôs Pearse St store, the back room of which has been turned into a studio for the occasion, the first thing we do is plop ourselves down on a nearby mattress.

It‚Äôs certainly the most comfortable wait we‚Äôve had for an interview, while the shop, like Mattress Mick, is bright, flashy, but also familiar.

It does what it says on the tin ‚Äì it‚Äôs not promising you anything more than you need. Indeed, Flynn (who comes from a family with a retail background) owned general furniture shops prior to the recession, but changed his focus to just the one product: mattresses.

Both Flynn and Kelly are all about focus. And they‚Äôre two men who know about surviving the rough times. Their work together has helped them both grow.

The documentary was meant to be a 10-minute film, but ‚Äúit took its own legs, basically‚Äù, says Flynn. That‚Äôs in part because they became better known, with Flynn being invited to turn up in character at a range of events, his fluffy white hair and large glasses ‚Äì as well as that toothy grin ‚Äì becoming his trademark.

Source: YouTube

‚ÄúI was going to be completely honest‚Äù

Flynn says he didn‚Äôt find the process intrusive ‚Äì but it‚Äôs a documentary that shows some of the rougher moments for himself and Kelly.

‚ÄúNow, there were some situations filmed that I would have liked to have been a little bit more private but they were there and [director] Colm [Quinn] did a good job in portraying them,‚Äù says Flynn.

‚ÄúWell, I found it strange to be in front of the camera rather than behind the camera,‚Äù says Kelly, for whom the process was a life-changing experience. When Quinn approached him to make the film, he was in debt, unemployed, and not living with his children. ‚ÄúMy life was completely downhill,‚Äù he says now. The documentary follows as he attempts to turn Mick Flynn into a star, and tries to turn his own life around in the process.

When he agreed to star in Mattress Men, he was going to be frank about what he was going through.

I was going to be completely honest and open because there are a lot of people in the same situation as I am‚Ä¶ I could easily give up, claim the social welfare and not do anything with my life, but I felt I was better than that and my story should be told, so it had to be completely 100% open in every circumstances and every situation within this film because that‚Äôs life, and this story really shows them hard times.

Being Mattress Mick

Because Mattress Mick is such a character, it‚Äôs tempting to think the man behind him is too.

But Flynn is, above all, and as the documentary shows, a businessman. He‚Äôs been through hard times ‚Äì he‚Äôs felt the impact of the recession on his life and pocket. He‚Äôs had to make difficult decisions and reinvent himself.

Though he and Kelly‚Äôs situations were different in some ways, at the heart they tell the same story of overcoming the odds.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think people would realise that I had the problems that I had, the financial problems and so forth,‚Äù says Flynn.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôll all find we had problems somewhere along the line and I opened up my problems to the world by saying I had problems and I think‚Ä¶ they‚Äôll see me just as a normal guy trying to sell mattresses, and more mattresses, and more mattresses.‚Äù

I would consider myself a serious businessman. I got into bother when the recession hit, things went wrong but I had to get going again, I had to survive and I had to prove myself to myself as well as to the people who would have known me.

His hope is that the film shows the darkness. ‚ÄúI hope that it encourages other people who may have been in the same situation as we were not to give up, to move on and to fight and to believe in yourself, that is the most important that to believe ‚Äì that you are capable of getting back up there, getting on top of your troubles and problems, do not let anyone interfere with you, just be totally focused on your own goals.

‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs what I did, and Paul is also doing the same,‚Äù assures Flynn, that grin replaced with a look of steely determination.

Source: YouTube

Thinking positively

For Kelly, the whole process has been a spiritual journey, he tells me. ‚ÄúAnd I know some people may think it‚Äôs crazy,‚Äù he smiles. ‚ÄúBut I had absolutely nothing and I was nowhere and I started reading positive books about visualising and setting yourself goals, the laws of the universe. And once I started believing in that, things started happening.‚Äù

He believes the pair were fated to work together, telling me that he used to pass Michael Flynn outside his Pearse St shop when he worked nearby 20 years ago.

‚ÄúI used to remember thinking to myself ‚Äòone day I‚Äôd like to be my own businessman and be that happy in my business‚Äô,‚Äù he recalls.

And in time, Kelly was able to set up his own company, Shoot Audition ‚Äì which provides an online platform for actors‚Äô auditions ‚Äì and Flynn was able to help him with office space and a way of making money.

It‚Äôs paying off ‚Äì Flynn says their business is getting stronger and they‚Äôre ‚Äúvery pleased‚Äù with how the film turned out.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs different, it‚Äôs quirky and it‚Äôs fun, but we couldn‚Äôt have done it, I couldn‚Äôt have done it on my own, Paul couldn‚Äôt have done it on his own, he needed a Mattress Mick and I needed a Paul, and it worked together.‚Äù

Any bad times, they ‚Äúovercame them because we both believe in our own destinies and we both believe we can get back on top again‚Äù.

‚ÄúHe gives me something back‚Äù

The pair‚Äôs relationship began in the most Irish of ways ‚Äì in a pub. They met in Flynn‚Äôs regular drinking hole, The Yacht.

‚ÄúHe was at a bad place in his business so we were meant to meet and do what we did together,‚Äù says Kelly now.

‚ÄúI would have had nothing: no business, no nothing if it wasn‚Äôt for Mick giving me the room space to grow and learn.‚Äù

He learned how to make the zany, effects-crammed Mattress Mick videos through YouTube tutorials.

In turn, Flynn has learned from him. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt have done it without Paul because I knew nothing about social media and I was used to advertising, for example, in newspapers. Like YouTube, Facebook, Twitter were all names that I knew but didn‚Äôt understand and Paul brought that into my life, and that‚Äôs how I think we work well together,‚Äù says Flynn, looking at his friend.

‚ÄúI can give him something, and he gives me something back.‚Äù

What‚Äôs their life philosophy?

Paul:

My one would be: The greatest souls are awakened out of suffering ‚Äì the most impressive personalities endure many scars.

Mick:

I can‚Äôt beat that one.

title: Dublin's Smithfield will be chockablock for the Busker Fleadh tomorrow
text:
Buskers Sam Brittain and Meg LaGrande at the launch of the Fleadh Source: Jason Clarke Photography

IF YOU‚ÄôRE KICKING your heels for something to do in Dublin tomorrow you could do a lot worse than checking out the city‚Äôs first Busker Fleadh.

Street performance is something that Dublin is pretty much synonymous with, and the Fleadh, which will run in conjunction with the Smithfield Stoneybatter Food Festival, is set to showcase the best of it, in the organisers‚Äô own words.

The Fleadh is being brought to us by Dublin City Council (DCC), with Lord Mayor Brendan Carr saying the event will bring us the best of the city‚Äôs ‚Äúvibrant music scene‚Äù.

Apart from bringing the cream of Ireland‚Äôs buskers together for a few short hours at Smithfield Square (the Fleadh kicks off at 12 noon and quits at 5pm), there will be quite a deal of other stuff to contend with.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôll be lots of food stalls and the High Hopes Choir will be on the scene as well,‚Äù says Fleadh organiser Kathryn Byrne.

Street performers from the Dublin Circus Project will be on hand, there‚Äôll be a special screening of Irish comedy-drama Sing Street in the Lighthouse Cinema, and the whole thing will be topped off with the Dublin Busker Competition.

Come and see the talented Charleen Murphy at the #BuskerFleadh from 12pm Sunday https://t.co/MpXRpMoDGL ‚Äî BuskerFleadh (@BuskerFleadh) October 5, 2016 Source: BuskerFleadh /Twitter

So there‚Äôs something in it for everyone.

The winner(s) of the Busker Competition will be gifted recording time at Windmill Lane Recording Studios and a digital download of their recordings worth ‚Ç¨1,000.

20 acts came through an open call to perform at the event, which will see four running through their sets each hour around the square. One of those is Wexford two-handers The Scenarios, made up of Thomas Furlong and William Carley.

‚ÄúWe formed about a year and a half ago while we were both up in St Pat‚Äôs,‚Äù the pair told TheJournal.ie. ‚ÄúWe started practicing together to try and raise money for a charity skydive ‚Äì that went well so we stuck with it.‚Äù

The two are an acoustic band, with both providing vocals, guitars, and, less expectedly, a ukulele. They picked up on a Facebook ad for the Fleadh a couple of months ago, just a number of weeks after they started gigging seriously.

The Scenarios

‚ÄúWe hope we‚Äôre in with a shout anyway,‚Äù Thomas says of the Busker Competition.

We played a wedding last night, but we‚Äôll be up fresh and early for the contest, and we‚Äôll give it our best.

Everyone seems to be very excited for the event in truth, with Kathryn Byrne affirming that all those involved can‚Äôt wait for it to begin.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre bursting with excitement for this, we‚Äôve been talking about this for two years and now it‚Äôs time to go,‚Äù she says.

title: Aer Lingus is hiring new cabin crew in recruitment drive
text:
AER LINGUS HAS launched a recruitment drive to fill new cabin crew positions for its Dublin base for next summer.

No previous cabin crew experience is required, to be eligible applicants must:

be 18 years of age or over

live and work in the Republic of Ireland

be fluent in English ‚Äì both spoken and written

hold a valid EEA Passport allowing unrestricted worldwide travel

have at least 12 months combined experience in a customer service/sales role

The cabin crew members will fly to over 100 destinations throughout UK, Europe and North America.

The airline stated that while there are a wide variety of responsibilities and duties involved ‚Äúultimately the job involves keeping every guest safe, while making their experience on board the best it can be‚Äù.

Crucial attributes include excellent communication and interpersonal skills and well-developed team-work skills.

Successful candidates will complete cabin crew training at Aer Lingus‚Äô in-house Training Academy, located in Dublin Airport.

#Open journalism No news is bad news Support The Journal Your contributions will help us continue to deliver the stories that are important to you Support us now

Applicants can apply online at careers.aerlingus.com, the closing date for applications is 21 October 2016.

title: There's a new online tool to help house buyers compare prices
text:
Source: Eamonn Farrell/Rollingnews.ie

THE CENTRAL STATISTICS Office (CSO) has today launched a new online tool to aid house buyers across the country.

The interactive portal, catchily-titled ‚ÄòHouse Prices by Eircode‚Äô takes your Eircode routing key (the first three characters of whatever code) and throws back price information for the area in question.

It‚Äôs very user-friendly, although more digging will be required if you‚Äôre searching for specific information.

You‚Äôll need to know your Eircode (which, let‚Äôs face it, you don‚Äôt), but a link to the online code finder is included. Alternatively, you can use the name of the area, but we found it quicker to search for the Eircode and then use that.

The information revealed isn't necessarily happy information unfortunately Source: CSO

Click here to view a larger image

The tool will tell you the average price of property in the area over the last 12 months (up to July 2016), together with comparisons between that asking price and the national average, and the contrast between new builds, second-hand, and unoccupied homes changing hands.

The volume of sales in the area for the last six years is also returned.

The blurb for the new option states that it is designed to work in conjunction with the Residential Property Price Register. Also, it says it ‚Äúharnesses the power of Eircodes‚Äù. Which is nice.

Evaluation? It‚Äôs quite slick and very worthwhile for a quick check, but given no drilldown detail is given on the types of home being talked about or the specific areas in which they fall, it‚Äôs probably best utilised as a starting point for buyers only.

It‚Äôs still pretty handy though. Check it out here.

title: Dublin manager Jim Gavin plays "groomsman" to 5,300 animals being airlifted to Africa
text:
Source: Diarmuid Greene/True Media

NOT CONTENT WITH managing the most dominant team in recent Gaelic Football history, Dublin manager Jim Gavin has taken charge of an altogether different kind of team bus.

Gavin, a commercial pilot and director with the Irish Aviation Authority when he‚Äôs not winning All Irelands, has served as one of two ‚Äúgroomsmen‚Äù to 5,300 animals that have been airlifted to Rwanda, Africa, on a flight from Shannon Airport where the beasts will serve as food and income producers for that country‚Äôs farmers.

On board the flight Source: Diarmuid Greene/True Media

Source: Diarmuid Greene/True Media

The cargo included 37 pregnant heifers, three bulls, 260 pigs, and 5,000 chickens, all bound for Rwanda on a flight known as the B√≥thar Ark, named for the Irish international aid agency who chartered the plane.

‚ÄúBehind the excitement behind this trip is immense generosity, great organisation and, at the end of the line, great hope,‚Äù Gavin said before embarking on the historic flight.

Upon arriving in Rwanda, the animals (the majority donated by Irish farmers, and up to six times more productive than the local Rwandan livestock) will be placed in quarantine to adjust to their new environment before being delivered to their recipient families.

Gavin himself first made contact with B√≥thar with regard to being involved with the airlift ‚Äì the 25th that the aid agency has undertaken.

‚ÄúWinning the All-Ireland is, of course, a privilege but this is also,‚Äù says Gavin.

To be able to witness first-hand the transformation of the lives of some of the poorest people in the world is definitely a privilege.

Source: Diarmuid Greene/True Media

CEO of B√≥thar DAve Moloney meanwhile says the airlift is the agency‚Äôs most important ever.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs our 25th anniversary so that has a lot of nostalgia for us but it‚Äôs also the biggest ever multi-species airlift in the world,‚Äù says Moloney.

title: An Apple-affiliated company is bringing 134 jobs to Limerick
text:
A TEXAS-BASED company that specialises in providing support to companies that use Apple devices is to create 134 jobs in Limerick.

The jobs at Trusource Labs will come on stream over the next three years as the company sets up a new international operations centre in the south-west.

In providing support for corporate Apple users, Trusource Labs is a member of the Apple Consultants Network and employs 600 people in the US.

The company has yet to give details about the type of jobs on offer but its co-founder Alton Martin said this morning that they will be related to ‚Äúcustomer experience‚Äù.

‚ÄúWe are enthusiastic to bring our innovative customer experience model to Ireland. It is our first step in a larger global growth plan and we are grateful for IDA‚Äôs partnership and support,‚Äù he said.

As Martin mentions, the jobs were supported by the IDA, with CEO Martin Shanahan describing Trusource‚Äôs decision to go to Limerick as ‚Äúa valuable reference case for IDA in attracting similar high growth technology companies to the region.‚Äù

Minister for Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation Mary Mitchell O‚ÄôConnor also said that the decision of the country to set up in Limerick demonstrated the government‚Äôs commitment to ‚Äújob creation right across the country.‚Äù

title: Your iPhone now has a hidden magnifying mode that you can use
text:
THE LATEST UPDATE to iOS brought a number of improvements to the formula, including one of the best parts of Apple‚Äôs software: Accessibility.

Alongside the usual options of reading out text and improving contrast, the latest version comes with a magnifier option which you can access in Accessibility.

To find it, go into Settings > General > Accessibility > Magnifier and turn it on. You also have the option of switching on auto-brightness too but it‚Äôs not necessary.

Once that‚Äôs done, triple-click the home button and you will see the magnifier option appear. Tap on it and you will go into a camera mode that‚Äôs zoomed in somewhat.

For those wondering why they couldn‚Äôt just use the camera instead, the answer is the different accessibility filters it uses.

While you can zoom in or out, you can adjust the brightness and contrast and use different filters which include white/blue, greyscale, and red/black. You can even invert the colours if you want.

And then there‚Äôs the shutter button which lets you avoid holding the phone for long periods. When you press it, you take a temporary photo of whatever is in front of you. From that you can move around or zoom out if necessary.

title: Thousands of nurses to see pay rise of at least ‚Ç¨1,000 next year
text:
Nurses take part in a pay restoration protest at Leinster House last month.

Nurses take part in a pay restoration protest at Leinster House last month.

UP TO 7,500 nurses and midwives will see an extra ‚Ç¨1,000 in next year‚Äôs total pay as certain increments are to be restored from 1 January 2017.

Health Minister Simon Harris announced today that nurses who graduated between 2011 and 2015 will have their incremental credit for their 36-week student placement restored.

The move has been welcomed by nurses and unions.

Speaking about the decision, Harris said it was clear to him that the issue was ‚Äúseverely impacting on conditions and morale‚Äù.

The Wicklow TD hopes that the pay rise will encourage Irish nurses working abroad to return home.

‚ÄúWe have major challenges recruiting and retaining nurses in this country but I believe this is a small step forward. We need our nurses to stay and we need our nurses to come home,‚Äù he said in a statement.

‚ÄúThis decision comes at the end of a long campaign to end this pay injustice and the two tier pay system that had developed and was having a detrimental effect on recruiting and retaining nurses,‚Äù added SIPTU organiser John McCamley.

‚ÄúThis is a small step in recognising the vital contribution that these nurses have made to our public health service.‚Äù

The INMO says that the pay rise could be up to ‚Ç¨1,500 for some of its members.

The union said the ‚Äúremoval of this anomaly involving the withholding of incremental credit for the fourth year of the undergraduate programme, sees the elimination of this very regressive measure which was introduced, unilaterally, in 2011‚Ä≥.

General secretary Liam Doran gave credit to the Minister for ‚Äúhis work on the issue since his appointment‚Äù.

title: Bob Dylan wins Nobel Prize for Literature
text:
BOB DYLAN HAS won the Nobel Prize for Literature.

The American singer was awarded the prize for ‚Äúhaving created new poetic expressions within the great American song tradition‚Äù.

The 75-year-old is the first songwriter to win the prestigious award after an announcement that surprised prize watchers.

Sara Danils, permanent Secretary of the Swedish Academy called Dylan a ‚Äúgreat sampler‚Äù.

‚ÄúFor 54 years he has been at it, reinventing himself.‚Äù

She praised his seminal Blonde on Blonde album.

‚ÄúAn extraordinary example of his brilliant way of rhyming. putting together refrains, and his pictorial thinking.

‚ÄúIf you want to start listening, you may start with Blonde on Blonde.

#Open journalism No news is bad news Support The Journal Your contributions will help us continue to deliver the stories that are important to you Support us now

‚ÄúHe is a great poet in the grand English poetic tradition.‚Äù

Asked whether she had spoken to him today, Danils said she hadn‚Äôt, but would speak to him this afternoon. She said she was not afraid of the notoriously gruff folk singer.

‚ÄúI have a good message.‚Äù

Dylan becomes the 259th American to have won a Nobel Prize.

title: What can Ireland's cities learn from the Night Mayor of Amsterdam?
text:
IT CAN‚ÄôT ALL be down to the eye-catching job title.

Paris, Toulouse and a raft of other cities across The Netherlands have adopted the idea of appointing a night mayor, following the success of Amsterdam‚Äôs ‚Äònighttime czar‚Äô.

London‚Äôs even following suit: new mayor Sadiq Khan recently published a job ad seeking someone to boost nightlife culture and promote the clubbing economy. And earlier this year, a panel debate took place in Dublin to discuss whether Ireland‚Äôs capital could benefit from the appointment of an official to look after the city, after dark.

So what does a night mayor actually do?

And how would the residents of Ireland‚Äôs cities stand to benefit, if the scheme was introduced in Dublin, Cork and elsewhere?

Source: Mirik Milan

Meet the Night Mayor

Mirik Milan, the current Night Mayor of Amsterdam (and the first person to hold that title anywhere, to our knowledge) will be speaking at a conference in the Docklands area of Dublin this week. Highlighting the positives of nighttime culture is a key part of his role, he said in a phone interview with TheJournal.ie.

Changing the narrative of nightlife is really important: people can benefit from it and they don‚Äôt have to feel like they‚Äôre doing something wrong to be involved in this industry.

Milan, a former club promoter, was appointed to the role in 2012, he explained. It had existed for around a decade before then, but was more of a nominal position - ‚Äùsomething you‚Äôd get as a nightlife person to raise your profile and to be cool‚Äù.

He created a small non-profit organisation partly funded by the city in 2014. With support from bars and clubs, has been working since then to improve life after dark for businesses and their customers ‚Äì acting as a bridge between the nightlife world and Amsterdam‚Äôs residents and officials.

But the focus isn‚Äôt on dealing with individual complaints from club-owners or residents, Milan explained.

‚ÄúWe focus on legislation ‚Äì what‚Äôs going on in the city, how we can get all the stakeholders together.

I would never just respond to a complaint from one person or respond to a request from a club ‚Äì maybe if there were three or four nightclubs saying ‚Äòwe all have the same problem with this piece of legislation, can we speak to City Hall?‚Äô ‚Ä¶ Then we make sure that people come to the table ‚Äì and then hopefully we can change the legislation or make it better for all sides.

There was enthusiasm for the project from the off, he said ‚Äì which Milan puts down to the ‚Äútypical pragmatic‚Äù approach to life in general in The Netherlands.

Source: Shutterstock/S.Borisov

24 hour party people

Already, the scheme has brought about some significant changes ‚Äì not least the introduction of 24-hour licences for a number of venues, so clubbers can enjoy their night and make the journey home at a time of their own choosing.

Said Milan:

‚ÄúThese 24 hour licences are not located in the city centre ‚Äì they‚Äôre located on the outskirts of the city, which can be developed more.

The venues can be open longer so more artists play there, and they are in the international spotlight. They can choose for themselves when to open and close ‚Äì this also makes sure that people don‚Äôt all spill out into the streets at the same time.

All of the above may conjure up images of illegal raves of the kind run in warehouses around suburban Dublin ‚Äì but the approach, Milan explained, couldn‚Äôt be more different. Applicants for the 24-hour licences faced stringent stipulations.

‚ÄúWhat was really radical about this is that the licences were not given out on the basis that there was four walls and a roof and a bouncer in front of the door ‚Äì they were given out on the basis of content.

It was focused on quality ‚Äì we asked people to send in their pitches with a focus on what we thought was beneficial.

Rather than the straightforward bar-nightclub approach, the 24-hour venues host a range of other events too ‚Äì including theatre and movie nights.

It‚Äôs more about the 24 hour economic system ‚Äì how to use a building more efficiently rather than just having clubbing seven days in a row.

The experiment has served to breath new life into suburban areas of Amsterdam, and ease pressure on the centre of the city.

We gave advice to the Mayor of London on how to install the role of the Night Mayor in London. here is a short interview I did with @NME https://t.co/ZSztGexa4h ‚Äî Mirik Milan (@Mirikmilan) September 26, 2016 Source: Mirik Milan /Twitter

Square hosts

Milan‚Äôs team, in cooperation with City Hall, has also spearheaded the introduction of ‚Äòsquare hosts‚Äô ‚Äì a 20-strong crew of trained social workers who patrol designated areas of the city at weekends, acting as ‚Äòsoft enforcement‚Äô personnel.

The hosts get to know their area and the regulars at the various clubs on their beat. Their responsibilities take in everything from giving out information on venues to tourists and other visitors, to stepping in to help curb potential outbreaks of violence.

Describing how it works, Milan said ‚Äúthe police are not so visible any more in the nightlife squares ‚Äì because it often gives a grim and sometimes oppressive feel to the nightlife area‚Äù.

So the police are now in the backstreet areas ‚Äì the square hosts are on the squares.

It works ‚Äúlike stewards at a football stadium,‚Äù he explained. ‚ÄúBecause the steward is also your friend and they support your team as well.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe role of the square host is to de-escalate the situation if they see a problem ‚Äì but also to give information about what‚Äôs going on in each nightclub and which bars play which kind of music.

‚ÄúThe square hosts know which people are the trouble-makers ‚Äì and they‚Äôre there each weekend, so the trouble-makers know they‚Äôre being watched as well because there‚Äôs, like, 20 square hosts every Friday and Saturday night, so there‚Äôs 20 extra sets of eyes on the streets.

If there‚Äôs a big problem, of course, they will inform the police and the police will go straight to it.

‚ÄòNot a hedonistic Valhalla‚Äô

The myriad responsibilities of the role Milan has carved out for himself take in everything from acting as a spokesperson in the media for his city‚Äôs nightlife culture, to heading up awareness campaigns to clarify drug use policies.

On the latter:

‚ÄúSome people think that The Netherlands are some kind of hedonistic Valhalla where you can do anything you like ‚Äì that‚Äôs not true. You get caught with an illegal substance, you will go home with a criminal record.

It‚Äôs the worst way to close off your holiday. Our focus is always on harm reduction and giving out the information people will actually use.

Last orders

Asked about the situation in Irish towns and cities at weekends, where pubs close around midnight and clubs shut their doors (all at once) just a few hours later, he says it can often lead to trouble.

I think it means between 12 and 2, it would be really busy on the street? A lot of problems happen when different groups of people meet each other on the street late at night ‚Äì so it‚Äôs much better to divide these people more over the night.

On a more general point, when it comes to changing licensing or related laws ‚Äúlegislators always think that their piece of legislation is going to create behavioural change ‚Äì but it‚Äôs not‚Äù.

Behavioural change comes from subcultures. They will influence mainstream culture so you have to invest in your subcultures and try to get people on board, because legislation has never done that.

Mirik Milan will be speaking at the Irish Property Developers Conference 2016 at the Marker Hotel in Dublin tomorrow.

title: Horgan: Five or six LOI players good enough to play for Ireland
text:
DUNDALK WINGER DARYL Horgan believes that there are‚Äùfive or six‚Äù players in the League of Ireland who would be good enough to play for the Republic of Ireland.

Horgan has been in impressive form for Stephen Kenny‚Äôs side this season, starring in the Champions League and Europa League, and chipping in with crucial goals as they compete for SSE Airtricity Premier Division and FAI Cup honours.

There has been a clamour for Martin O‚ÄôNeill to include the 24-year-old in his Ireland squad and the Boys in Green boss revealed that if Dundalk‚Äôs schedule was not so tight, he would be in the panel.

Horgan admitted that it would be ‚Äúfantastic‚Äù to be included, but also stressed that more SSE Airtricity League players have what it takes to compete on the international stage.

‚ÄúIf I can do well in that maybe Martin might decide to bring me into the squad,‚Äù Horgan told Newstalk‚Äôs ‚ÄòOff the Ball‚Äò.

‚ÄúAt this moment in time, I‚Äôm not in the squad, but it‚Äôd be fantastic for myself and to be honest with you, I think Martin, it‚Äôs just not me he‚Äôs looking at. I think there‚Äôs definitely four or five or six players in the league he could bring in.‚Äù

The Galway native added: ‚ÄùI suppose the school of thought was you have to be away [in Britain], but maybe at this stage now, the fact that ourselves and Cork have done well in Europe and proved it against internationals and big players from big countries, [it shows] that maybe there is quality in the league and players are able to make that step up.‚Äù

Dundalk‚Äôs free-scoring talisman last season, Richie Towell, moved to Championship side Brighton and Hove Albion, but has struggled for game time since making the switch to Britain.

A number of British clubs were also keen on Horgan, but, despite trials with clubs such as Peterborough United and Barnsley, he opted to remain at Oriel Park, where he has since experienced high-level Champions League encounters and is now competing in the Europa League.

‚ÄúTo be honest, it‚Äôs probably one of the biggest lessons I could ever have had,‚Äù Horgan said, reflecting on his trials in England.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve got to play constantly here in the first team and in the Europa League and winning leagues. It‚Äôs been special the last couple of years.

‚ÄúI thought they went well, but a couple of weeks after both trials, managers were sacked.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs so cut-throat. You could easily end up signing for a club and the manager could be sacked two days later, another fella might come in and not fancy you, so it was probably a blessing.‚Äù

title: Newborn baby revived by Dublin Fire Brigade after "unexpected" home birth
text:
File photo Source: Sam Boal/Rollingnews.ie

AN UNEXPECTED HOME birth in west Dublin has had a happy ending after the arrival of Dublin Fire Brigade.

In the wake of the home birth, which happened in the Tallaght area at the weekend, the newborn baby stopped breathing.

Responding to an unexpected home birth at the weekend, the fire engine and ambulance from Tallaght successfully resuscitated the 1/2 pic.twitter.com/IVkDCnQ3aA ‚Äî Dublin Fire BOOgadeüëª (@DubFireBrigade) October 13, 2016 Source: Dublin Fire Brigade /Twitter

However, the attending ambulance crew and fire officers, who included an advanced paramedic amongst their ranks, were able to resuscitate the baby and take care of the mother.

Mother and baby are understood to be doing fine.

title: 8-week-old puppies seized being exported to Scotland
text:
TEN PUPPIES WERE seized at a port in Scotland yesterday after being imported illegally and were returned to Belfast.

The pups ‚Äì five basset hounds and five pug crosses ‚Äì are all about eight weeks old and are too young to travel.

The dogs were not microchipped and didn‚Äôt have pet passports, which are required to travel to the UK.

They were handed over to the care of the ISPCA and are currently receiving veterinary treatment. The pups all appear to be in good health and should be available for rehoming in the coming weeks.

Commenting on the rescue, ISPCA CEO Dr Andrew Kelly said that the attempted exporting of the dogs was ‚Äúanother example of the illegal behaviour of dog breeders in Ireland‚Äù.

‚ÄúPuppies like these are transported at a vulnerable age and many are too young to be separated from their mothers, let alone endure the journey to the UK,‚Äù he said.

In addition, all puppies must be microchipped and registered before leaving their place of birth, which these were not. We would also like to appeal to anyone who is looking for a dog to act responsibly and consider adopting from a rescue rather than buying one.

The ISPCA said that the rescue was just one of a number of seizures of puppies at Cairnryan port over the past few months totalling 40.

They were taken as part of Operation Delphin, which is a joint operation targeting the illegal export of puppies from Ireland to the UK.

title: 'This is life changing, a once in a lifetime win for my family': Carer wins ‚Ç¨500,000
text:
A CARER who looks after members of his own family told of his delight after scooping ‚Ç¨500,000 in the Euromillions.

The man, who wants to remain anonymous, bought his winning ticket at the Drive Centra in Carna Cushinstown in Ballinaboola, Wexford on Tuesday 11 October

The winner said: ‚ÄúThis is a life changing, once in a lifetime win for my family. I am a full time carer for members of my family and we were living from week to week on my carer‚Äôs allowance.

‚Ç¨500,000 will make a huge difference to our lives and it will take the everyday pressures of making ends meet away for a long time.

‚ÄúI have worked hard all of my life to take care of my family and those around me. This money will go a long to make sure that we are all secure for many years to come.‚Äù

Lotto winners

Another winner arrived in Lotto HQ in Dublin‚Äôs Abbey Street with his two of his friends who had no idea what was going on.

The young man from Clare, who won just under ‚Ç¨200,000, explained: ‚ÄúI asked the two lads to come with me to Dublin today but I didn‚Äôt tell where we were going.

‚ÄúI could have come on my own but I wanted to share the experience with my two best friends. I‚Äôm going to enjoy the win over the next couple of days but first, I have plans to pay off my mortgage and we will see what is left after that.‚Äù

title: Half a century ago Colin saved a girl from drowning; today he wants to find out what happened to her
text:
The old Bridge at North Beach in Greystones.

The old Bridge at North Beach in Greystones.

This story was updated on 10/10/16

COLIN WILDE SAVED a young girl‚Äôs life 50 years ago, but he never learned her name.

In the summer of 1967, when Colin was 12, he travelled from his hometown of Kippax, West Yorkshire, on a school trip to Greystones in Wicklow.

Colin remembers the trip fondly.

On a bright summer‚Äôs day, the group headed to nearby Bray to go for a swim. As Colin remembers, the weather was fine but the sea was freezing ‚Äì too cold to go swimming.

He recalls that after tea at the youth hostel where they were staying, the group had walked down Main Street towards the beach.

‚ÄúThere was a metal bridge over the railway lines to the beach,‚Äù Colin told TheJournal.ie over the phone from his home in England.

‚ÄúI was walking over there and then I just heard this horrible screaming ‚Äì gurgling screaming,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI looked towards the sea and I saw this young girl drowning, no two ways about it she was just drowning.

‚ÄúSo I raced over the bridge to the beach, took my clothes off ‚Äì luckily I had my swimming trunks on ‚Äì I swam out and I pulled her back in. I never even thought about it, I just went in and grabbed her arm and got back out. And that‚Äôs the last I ever saw of her. Colin Wilde

Memory

Colin never found out the girl‚Äôs name or what happened to her after that day.

‚ÄúSome adults that were there and they turned her on her side and got the sea water out of her lungs,‚Äù he said.

The last I saw of her she was getting sick up water on the beach. I just picked my clothes up and went back to the youth hostel.

He remembers that she was fully clothed when he rescued her, wearing a big duffel jacket. He doesn‚Äôt know how she got into the water.

He recalls the walk back to the hostel. He was stripped down to his trunks and shivering and an elderly woman brought him back to her house to warm him up with a cup of tea.

Greystones main street 1960s. Source: Harry Acheson via Greystones Guide

When he got back to the hostel, Colin said he was interviewed by a local paper (he can‚Äôt remember which paper), and a story appeared the next day about the event.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know whether it was the coldness of the water or the shock of what had happened, but I‚Äôd lost my voice, I couldn‚Äôt even talk,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI had a friend with me and he told the newspaper what had happened.

The only way I know she survived is because the newspaper clipping said I had saved her life.

The newspaper in question was the Irish Press. An article that appeared on Saturday, 20 May 1967, detailed Colin‚Äôs rescue:

The original article detailing Colin's rescue. Source: Irish Press

Colin returned to England a few days after the rescue, and his life continued as normal.

Shortly after, he received a certificate from Dublin commending him for saving the girl‚Äôs life, which gave her age as 16, but no name.

A report from Tuesday, 12 December mentions Colin again as being awarded a certificate of bravery from Leinster House.

Source: Irish Press

The years passed and Colin grew up, became a sheet metal fabricator by trade and worked most of his life as a site manager.

Today he is retired and living in Kippax, the same small village where he grew up. He is married with three children and two grandchildren.

A shopfront in Kippax. Source: Alan Burnett via Flickr

Recently, when he was telling his grandchildren about the day, he realised that he had lost the newspaper clipping.

‚ÄúI just don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs happened to it. I‚Äôve looked everywhere now.‚Äù

Appeal

Colin is an avid fisherman. He has returned to Ireland on many occasions over the years on trips and holidays.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve always had an affinity with Ireland, I can‚Äôt really explain it,‚Äù he said.

I‚Äôve just always really like it there.

Throughout his life he has often thought of the girl he saved that day in Greystones and what had happened to her.

‚ÄúI still remember that horrible gurgling sound. The sound of trying to scream but your lungs are full of water‚Ä¶ I‚Äôll never forget it,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve always wondered what happened to her‚Ä¶ what she was doing in the water that day.

I don‚Äôt want any adoration or anything I was just curious to know whether she‚Äôd had a good life.

Do you know anything about this story or the people involved? Contact cormac@thejournal.ie to get in touch.

title: An Irish conference for the Snapchat generation has caught the eye of foreign entrepreneurs
text:
A NEW IRISH ‚Äòwellbeing‚Äô conference for the Snapchat generation has been attracting attention from abroad ‚Äì before it has even opened its doors for the first time.

The inaugural Zeminar youth summit takes place at the RDS, Dublin from Tuesday to Thursday, and founder Damien Clarke told Fora he has already been approached by social entrepreneurs looking to replicate the event in Australia and Britain.

Around 15,000 young people aged 15 to 20, parents and teachers are expected to attend the conference, where they will learn about issues like mental health and what to do after secondary school.

A number of high-profile people will speak at the event, including musician Bressie, Twitter Ireland boss Mark Little and former Rose of Tralee Maria Walsh.

Bressie Source: Sasko Lazarov/Photocall Ireland

‚ÄúThe beauty of this event is that it doesn‚Äôt need to move around to other cities,‚Äù Clarke said. ‚ÄúIt can happen simultaneously throughout the world.‚Äù

He said that while the response from abroad has been ‚Äúencouraging‚Äù, he wants to ‚Äúmake sure we get our own template right‚Äù before selling the concept.

‚ÄúThat might take two years to happen. After that, we will look to see if we can franchise it out to other countries.‚Äù

Research

Clarke, a former Web Summit employee with a background in psychology, came up with the idea for Zeminar two years ago.

‚ÄúI spent a year researching the idea, going to schools, meeting with young people, teachers, parents all over the country and got a sense that there was a demand for a new type of event that covers all of the different interests and issues that young people have.‚Äù

He set up a crowdfunding campaign to get the initiative off the ground.

He raised over ‚Ç¨15,000 in a Fund It campaign that generated a bit of media attention, which Clarke said ‚Äúwas a nice platform‚Äù to attract speakers.
